messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:25): hsivonen_: really unuseful error message: it told me that on line 60000, when it hit the </body>, it had some unclosed elements
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:25): hsivonen_: which ones? what lines did they start on?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:26): needs to be less good at procrastinating
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:30): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: You need to get better at procrastinating, so you can direct it towards tasks that weren't worth doing anyway
84624b0535ba57fbd2aef0b147c25270 (01:36): probably similar to http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=440

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:43): if the people who comment on sam's blog would instead take part in the actual official mailing lists, we might drown out the nonsense on public-html with at least semi-sane discussion
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:07): given the following sentence:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:07): The DOM attribute relList must reflect the rel content attribute
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:07): ...can you come up with a way of phrasing it whereby it means the same as that, but by only removing characters, you can get it to mean the equivalent of:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:08): The DOM attribute relList reflects the rel content attribute
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:11): What's that s doing to cause trouble?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:13): mostly, it's grammatically required
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:13): if you can get an s into the first one that works too
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:15): me gets confused by the question
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:15): wonders why 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e needs that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:16): the former is what i need for the full spec, the second is what i need for the author-only spec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:16): but for QA purposes i really want to keep the second a pure subset of the former
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:16): <span class="main-spec-only">s</span> :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:16): you mean author-spec-only?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:17): that unfortunately doesn't satisfy my "keep the second a pure subset of the former" goal :-)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:17): You'd have the tag in both specs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:18): there is only one spec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:18): and one tag, which hides stuff from the author version
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:18): And you do the opposite with this
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:18): hiding from the main version is what i'm trying to avoid
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:19): because then the specs aren't a pure subset of each other
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:19): and QA becomes a huge pain
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:19): because you have to always check things in two specs
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:19): You need a script that magically fixes grammar issues, while removing RFC2119 keywords :P
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:20): "must always be in a state where it reflects"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:20): hm, interesting approach
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:21): tweets his feelings
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:21): I don't think it's possible to do without looking silly
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:21): types /invite a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 into his #twitter channel
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:21): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: What do you think of that, so far, BTW?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:21): effing awesome
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:22): makes twitter usable
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:22): used the IM interface till that died
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:22): Is it real time, or do tweets come bunched together?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:22): having the same interface for msn, yahoo, aim, icq, jabber, freenode, moznet, w3net, quakenet, operanet, and twitter is pretty spectacularly awesometastic.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:22): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: it polls every 2 minutes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:23): or something like that
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:23): That sucks a bit.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:23): feels real time
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:23): since i only check irc every 2 minutes or so :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:23): and so far people haven't replied anywhere near that fast
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:23): :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:24): sod it, i'll use an author-only class
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:24): but it's for grammar only!
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:24): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: What do you use for IM?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:24): bitlbee
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:25): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: How does that show who is online? I guess you need to manually poll using ISON?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:26): when they come online they join the channel
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:26): when they are away they get -v, and when they are not away they get +v
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:26): It seem a bit like trying to shoehorn things into IRC
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:26): how so?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:27): i mean, it is, but it seems like a near perfect fit
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:27): Well, most IM clients have proper ways to note whether people are away or not without misusing some other feature for it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:27): if irssi did /away polling, i'd see if bitlbee supported using that instead
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:27): but i prefer seeing the mode changes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:27): it works well
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:28): and it works in all im clients
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:28): er, irc clients
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:28): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: i can;t use the class actually, because then it means you must use css to view the spec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:29): uh huh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:31): one option is to go through and change all the uses of the term reflect to be definitions instead of requirements
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:31): and move the requirement to the definition of "Reflect"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:31): but that would be a huge pain
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:32): all of this is a one-time pain
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:32): the easier option is to hide the entire paragraph and use a domintro thingy instead
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:32): another option is to say that all attributes that are omitted reflect by default
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:33): One-time as in it won't hurt if you write new sections, since the pain is only rewriting and not writing.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:33): yes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:33): i dunno if it's a good idea though
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:36): plays around with BitlBee
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:38): Heh
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (02:38): realizes everyone is away on IM
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:48): ok problem solved
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:48): i'll just hide all these paragraphs and rely on a summary table that future ian will write
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:59): does future Ian have a lot more time on his hands than existing Ian?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:01): actually yes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:01): future ian has a whole week in august for writing summary tables
